intro: Echidnopsis milleri, commonly known as the Miller's ghost flower, is a unique member of the Asparagaceae family native to the arid regions of Western Australia. It is a perennial herb that produces striking, pale blue or violet flowers with a distinctive, almost ghostly appearance. The plant is characterized by its fleshy, succulent leaves and a short, robust stem. It blooms during the cooler months, typically from July to September, and relies on specific environmental conditions for successful germination. Due to its rarity and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a threatened species in its native range.
